Description: Rim sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; frieze of alternating lotus flowers and palmette in added outline with added red centres; exterior: band at rim; below, frieze of alternating red and black tongues, above zigzags between pairs of bands.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.537 and belongs to the same vase as 1888,0601.465.a, 1888,0601.465.b, 1888,0601.465.d, 1888,0601.465.e, Paris E8056 bis.22, London UCL 751, UCL 393 and Boston 88.830. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965,0930.338. Lemos describes other sherds from the vase as coming from a mediocre, but big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1571) (phase 2)
